Do you want to know a secret? (Do da do)
 Do you promise not to tell? (Do da do) Whoa oh, oh

This song was later given to another Epstein-managed act, Billy J Kramer and the Dakotas, who had a hit with it the following year.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lDCkdaSs_vg
You’ll never know how much I really love you

This song was written by John Lennon alone, in Brian Epstein’s old Liverpool flat (which he used for his homosexual trysts to keep it hidden from his family). He later gave it to Lennon and his first wife as a wedding present and it became their maritial home. Lennon said:

I was in the first apartment I’d ever had that wasn’t shared with fourteen other students – gals and guys at art school. I’d just married Cyn, and Brian Epstein gave us his secret little apartment that he kept in Liverpool for his sexual liaisons separate from his home life. And he let Cyn and I have that apartment.

Say the words you long to hear
 I’m in love with you, ooh

The Beatles recorded at least seven takes of this song on 11th February 1963, and take six was chosen for the album cut.

Harrison said of his contribution:

[That song] was ‘my song’ on the album. I didn’t like my vocal on it. I didn’t know how to sing, nobody told me how to.

It also fit Harrison’s image as the quiet, young doo-wop child of the group. McCartney and Lennon reinforce this style with some simple doo-wop backing vocals overdubbed after the live takes.

Listen (Do da do)
 Do you want to know a secret? (Do da do)
 Do you promise not to tell? (Do da do) Whoa oh, oh

Lennon was inspired to write this song after the Disney tune Wishing Well, from the movie Snow White & The Seven Dwarfs, which his mother Julia would often sing to him:

My mother was… a comedienne and a singer. Not professional, but, you know, she used to get up in pubs and things like that. She had a good voice. She could do Kay Starr. She used to do this little tune when I was just a one or two year old… yeah, she was still living with me then… The tune was from the Disney movie – ‘Want to know a secret? Promise not to tell. You are standing by a wishing well.’

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2hpWF0xx6vk

Let me whisper in your ear
 Say the words you long to hear
 I’m in love with you, ooh

Lennon and McCartney would often write tracks with George or Ringo in mind, and would tailor their vocal melodies if they thought it would be a good fit for one of their colleagues.

George had yet to develop his own melodic voice, and Ringo was never a born singer, so in order to adapt Lennon-McCartney wrote deliberately simple melodies that wouldn’t challenge the small ranges of Harrison and Starr. It was also a practice they used when writing With A Little Help From My Friends.

Lennon said:

I wrote it and just gave it to George to sing. I thought it would be a good vehicle for him because it only had three notes and he wasn’t the best singer in the world. He has improved a lot since then, but in those days his singing ability was very poor because (a) he hadn’t had the opportunity, and (b) he concentrated more on the guitar. So I wrote that – not for him as I was writing it, but when I had written it, I thought he could do it. It was just written.

Listen
 Do you want to know a secret?
 Do you promise not to tell? Whoa oh, oh

This song was written for George Harrison to sing, as was the standard in the early Beatles days when Lennon and McCartney were the only two songwriting forces within the group.

Harrison would not pen an original lyric until their second album and his song Don’t Bother Me.
